Why it Matters: Potential credit from recycling valuable scrap material.
Time spent carefully covering features that should not be plated.
Labor and machine time to cut the raw stock to a usable size.
QC department time using hand tools.
Time to document the exact tools, holders, and offsets for a job.
Time spent preparing the blank with initial flat and parallel surfaces.
The time the CMM takes to automatically inspect a part.
Admin time to create detailed work instructions for the shop floor.
Time spent texturing or cleaning surfaces.
When an assembly requires minor secondary machining like drilling final alignment holes, reaming, or prepping components for fitment.
Typical Price Swing*: Billed at a standard CNC Machinist rate ($85–$130/hr).

Why it Matters: Using software to check for crashes and errors before running.
Generally faster than 3D, but still a skilled labor cost.
A percentage added to account for the statistical likelihood of some bad parts.
Typical Price Swing*: 1–5% to total material and labor cost.

Why it Matters: Labor for final, critical operations like jig grinding a bore to match a shaft post-assembly or using EDM to create a final feature.
Typical Price Swing*: Billed at the specific machine/skill rate (e.g., Jig Grind @ $110–$160/hr).

Why it Matters: High-skill labor for achieving very flat surfaces or precise bores.
Setups, precision fitting, jig grind calls, solving tolerance stackups
Typical Price Swing*: Billed at a standard journeyman rate ($85–$130/hr).

Why it Matters: Time spent achieving a mirror or optical finish.
Each tool requires a tool change, adding to non-cutting time.
Typical Price Swing*: 15–60 seconds per tool; can be significant.

Why it Matters: Time to program the Coordinate Measuring Machine.
Time for a skilled programmer to create toolpaths for a mill.
Labor and machine time to create the custom copper or graphite electrode.
Operator time spent checking parts at the machine.
Toolmaker time to assemble and qualify the custom fixture.
Complex projects with many milestones require dedicated management time.
The percentage added to the total cost to arrive at the final price.
The purchase cost of all fasteners and components to be installed.
Hourly cost for precision surface grinding.
Hourly cost for cylindrical grinding.
Total pieces of raw stock needed for the job.
The direct cost charged by the carrier.
Cost of the abrasive wheel and the time spent preparing it.
Each re-fixturing of the part adds significant labor.
Cost of consumable turning inserts.
Long lead-time materials can delay the entire project.
Typical Price Swing*: Can add weeks to lead time; +$100s in expedite fees.

Why it Matters: Cost of the raw materials for the fixture.
Cost of consumable cutters, amortized over the job.
If the job requires less than the MOQ, you must buy and store the excess.
Typical Price Swing*: Can increase material cost by 100-500% for small jobs.

Why it Matters: Time for installing hardware (helicoils, dowel pins, bearings).
Time to separate the finished part from the bar stock.
Time the machine spends eroding the feature.
Time spent on internal features.
Time spent machining the outside diameter.
Estimated time the machine spends on bulk material removal.
The primary driver of EDM cost.
Time for passes that prepare surfaces for the final cut.
Time for the final, precise passes that determine surface finish and accuracy.
Time for creating threads.
Hourly cost for the specific VMC or HMC being used.
Example Values / Options: 3‑Axis VMC, 4‑Axis (rotary), 3+2 Positional, 5‑Axis Simultaneous, HMC, Lathe, Mill‑Turn, Wire EDM, Sinker EDM, Surface Grind, Cylindrical Grind

Why it Matters: The primary driver of cost per pound/kilogram.
Example Values / Options: Aluminum 6061‑T6, Aluminum 7075‑T6, Stainless 304, Stainless 316, Stainless 17‑4 PH, Tool Steel A2, Tool Steel D2, Tool Steel O1, Tool Steel S7, Tool Steel H13, Carbide K10, Carbide K20, Carbide K40, Copper C110, Brass 360, Titanium Ti‑6Al‑4V, Inconel 718

Why it Matters: Is NRE a separate line item or amortized into the part price?
Typical Price Swing*: Affects unit price vs. initial invoice structure.
Example Values / Options: Amortize over lot, One‑time line item, Include in unit price, Waive

Why it Matters: Pre-hardened material is more expensive and slower to machine.
Example Values / Options: Annealed, Pre‑Hardened, Hardened, Aged / Precip‑Hardened, As‑Rolled

Why it Matters: Engineering time to design custom workholding.
Example Values / Options: Auto‑Estimate, Force Include, Skip / Not Required

Why it Matters: Poor quality models require repair time.
Example Values / Options: Clean, Minor Heal, Major Heal, STL Mesh Only, 2D Drawing Only

Why it Matters: Incomplete RFQs add significant time for clarification.
Example Values / Options: Complete, Missing Drawing, Missing Tolerances, Missing Material, Missing Finish/Coating, Other Missing Info

Why it Matters: History of frequent revisions suggests a higher risk of mid-production changes.
Typical Price Swing*: 5–10% contingency on labor and management costs.
Example Values / Options: Low, Medium, High, Strict Traceability, Uncontrolled (no rev)

Why it Matters: A percentage to cover coolants, oils, cleaning supplies, etc.
Net 60/90 terms affect cash flow and may require adding a financing cost.
Typical Price Swing*: 1–3% of total price for terms beyond Net 30.
Example Values / Options: Prepay, COD, Net 30, Net 45, Net 60, Net 90, Milestone / Progress

Why it Matters: New customers may require more vetting and have higher perceived risk.
Typical Price Swing*: ~+/- 5% on margin depending on trust and history.
Example Values / Options: New, Existing, Key Account, Strategic, Dormant, At‑Risk

Why it Matters: Vendor price for anodizing, black oxide, nickel plating, etc.
Example Values / Options: None, Anodize Type II, Anodize Type III (Hard), Black Oxide, Zinc, Nickel Plate, Tin, Gold, Passivation, Powder Coat

Why it Matters: Vendor price for hardening, annealing, or stress relieving.
Example Values / Options: None, Anneal, Normalize, Harden & Temper, Carburize, Nitriding, Austemper

Why it Matters: Compliance adds significant overhead, auditing, and documentation costs.
Typical Price Swing*: 10–25% to total quote price as a compliance adder.
Example Values / Options: None, ITAR, AS9100, ISO 9001, PPAP (Level 3), FAI, RoHS, REACH

Why it Matters: Time for a person to manually remove sharp edges with hand tools.
Example Values / Options: None, Light Edge Break (0.2–0.3 mm), Standard Deburr, Full Cosmetic, Micro‑Deburr (under magnification)

Why it Matters: Affects initial sawing/prep time and material utilization (yield).
Example Values / Options: Plate, Bar Stock, Sheet, Tube, Extrusion, Casting, Forging, Additive Blank

Why it Matters: Adds complexity and cost but can reduce setups.
Typical Price Swing*: Increases machine rate but can save hours of setup labor.

Why it Matters: Time to wrap and box parts for safe transit.
Example Values / Options: Standard Box, Custom Crate, ESD Bagging, Vacuum Seal, Returnable Container

Why it Matters: Very large or heavy stock requires cranes and multiple people to handle.
Example Values / Options: Standard, Heavy (>50 lb), Oversize (>24 in), Requires Forklift

Why it Matters: Rush quotes require immediate attention, pulling estimators off other work.
A percentage to cover rent, utilities, office staff, and other business costs.
The direct purchase price from the supplier.
Example Values / Options: The formula fetches this cost from a MaterialData table based on the Material Selection input.

Why it Matters: Hourly cost for the specific turning machine.
Example Values / Options: The formula fetches this hourly rate from a MachineRates table.

Why it Matters: A factor to cover the risk of damage or loss during production.
High-skill labor for custom fitting, resolving tolerance stack-ups, and making final adjustments to tenths-level precision.
Typical Price Swing*: Billed at a premium Tool & Die Maker rate ($100–$150/hr).

Why it Matters: Labor for creating detailed assembly instructions, taking photos, and documenting procedures for complex, multi-part assemblies.
Typical Price Swing*: Billed at a Process Engineer rate ($110–$160/hr).

Why it Matters: Cost to build a custom wooden crate for large or delicate items.
Time spent analyzing a design and suggesting cost-saving changes.
A batch process for automated deburring of many parts.
Machine time for adding part numbers or logos.
Process for cleaning and protecting materials like stainless steel.
A very high-cost, high-precision machine.
Hourly cost for the wire EDM machine.
Hourly cost for the sinker machine.
Reduces labor but may carry a higher machine rate.
Reduces cycle time but requires more programming and a capable machine.
Typical Price Swing*: -10–40% on cycle time; +10% on programming time.

Why it Matters: Requires special, expensive tooling and slower, more careful machining.
Typical Price Swing*: 50–200% on cycle time for those features; +$200 on tooling.

Why it Matters: A multiplier to account for slower, chatter-prone machining.
Typical Price Swing*: 25–100% on cycle time for delicate features.

Why it Matters: Expedited jobs require overtime, schedule disruption, and premium shipping.
Typical Price Swing*: 25–100% on total price; depends on severity.

Why it Matters: Handling CFM requires tracking, inspection, and assumes liability for scrap.
Admin time to create the detailed documentation package.
Need to accommodate a customer representative witnessing inspection.
Typical Price Swing*: 2–4 hours of QC labor for coordination (+$150–$300).

Why it Matters: Cost to design and build a custom gauge for a specific feature.
Enables automation for high-volume jobs, reducing labor.
Cycle time for milled features done on the lathe.
Typical Price Swing*: Billed at the higher mill-turn machine rate.

Why it Matters: Enables working on the back side of a part in one setup.
Need for custom-ground tools for special profiles adds NRE.
The cost of the consumable brass or coated wire.
